title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: This study examined the degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by the endophytic fungus Aspergillus bridgerii in a microcosm setting. The microcosm consisted of a controlled environment with specific temperature, humidity, and light conditions. The researchers evaluated the degradation of the fabric using scanning electron microscopy (scanning electron microscopy) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The results showed that Aspergillus bridgerii significantly degraded the nonwoven fabric in the microcosm, with the degradation rate increasing over time. The scanning electron microscopy images revealed morphological changes in the fabric, including the formation of holes and the breakdown of fibers. The FTIR spectra indicated changes in the chemical composition of the fabric, including the degradation of polypropylene and polyethylene components.   the capacity of Aspergillus bridgerii to degrade nonwoven fabric in surgical masks, a material commonly used in medical settings to prevent the transmission of pathogens. The degradation of this material by the fungus raises questions about the potential for Aspergillus bridgerii to also accumulate and metabolize diverse materials, including those used in medical equipment and infrastructure. The tension between the pathogenic potential of Aspergillus bridgerii and its capacity to degrade and accumulate materials underscores the complex and multifaceted relationships between humans, nonhumans, and the built environment in the Anthropocene.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: This study investigated the toxicological interactions between Aspergillus fumigatus, a commonly found indoor mold species, and two air fresheners, Brands A and B. The researchers evaluated the cytotoxic effects of each component on A549 cells, and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. They also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry). The results showed that both air fresheners contained compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions influenced the toxicological interactions between the mold and the air fresheners.  the importance of considering the interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air in assessing their health impacts, and suggests that air freshener manufacturers can formulate products with minimal health impacts by understanding these interactions.   The co-existence of Aspergillus fumigatus and air fresheners in indoor environments reveals a complex entanglement of biotic and abiotic factors, where the same compounds that inhibit mold growth in air fresheners also pose health risks to humans. This study underscores the need for a nuanced understanding of indoor air health impacts, one that accounts for the dynamic interplay between living organisms and their chemical environments.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This study reports the development of a natural antifungal strategy using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO) against Alternaria alternata, a pathogen causing postharvest diseases in tomatoes. The LEO was extracted via an optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), achieving a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro experiments demonstrated potent antifungal activity of LEO against A. alternata, with an IC₅₀ of 0.0718 μL/mL. In vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed that LEO significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, indicating a multi-target antifungal mechanism. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed the safety of LEO, supporting its potential application as a natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.  Through the Patchy Anthropocene lens, this research highlights the entangled relationships between human, nonhuman, and material worlds. The development of LEO as a natural preservative for postharvest disease control reflects the ongoing struggle to mitigate the impacts of human activities on food safety and shelf life. The material specificity of the extraction method and the chemical composition of LEO underscore the complex interplay between natural and industrial processes in shaping the properties of this antifungal agent. While LEO offers a promising solution for postharvest disease control, its production and application are embedded in broader networks of labor, capital, and environmental transformation, revealing the intricate dependencies and power dynamics at play in the Anthropocene.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: This study employed ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry) and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy) to screen for, assess the risk of, and rapidly detect mycotoxins in edible herbs. Mycotoxins were isolated from 20 edible herbs and identified using ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. The results showed that mycotoxins were detected in 14 of the 20 herbs, with the highest concentrations found in herbs from China. The minimum detection limits for aflatoxins, ochratoxin A, and fumonisins were 0.01, 0.1, and 0.1 micrograms per kilogram, respectively. The study found that Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy spectroscopy could be used to rapidly detect mycotoxins in edible herbs, but with lower sensitivity than ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. The study suggests that the combination of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy spectroscopy could be used for the rapid detection and risk assessment of mycotoxins in edible herbs.  The findings of this study highlight the entanglement of human and nonhuman relations in the Anthropocene. On one hand, the detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs reveals the threat posed by these organisms to human health, particularly in regions such as China where mycotoxin contamination is a significant concern. On the other hand, the use of Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy spectroscopy as a rapid detection method also underscores the capacity of technologies to metabolize and adapt to external stresses, thereby revealing deeper dependencies between human and nonhuman systems.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: This study examines the effect of hyperglycemic conditions on the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol are mycotoxins produced by fungi, specifically Alternaria species and Fusarium species, respectively. The mycotoxins were tested on human colon cancer cells in vitro, with the cells exposed to varying concentrations of glucose to simulate hyperglycemic conditions. The study found that hyperglycemic conditions modulated the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins, with increased glucose levels altering the expression of genes involved in cell survival and apoptosis. The results suggest that hyperglycemic conditions may influence the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to mycotoxins, potentially impacting the development and progression of colon cancer. The study's findings have implications for understanding the role of hyperglycemia in cancer development and the potential use of mycotoxins as therapeutic agents.  The capacity of fungi to produce mycotoxins like alternariol and deoxynivalenol creates a tension between the organisms' potential as pathogens and their potential as resources. The study's findings on the influence of hyperglycemic conditions on colon cancer cells' response to these mycotoxins underscore the complex interplay between human, fungal, and environmental factors in the development and progression of cancer.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: This paper presents a critical analysis of various nanomaterials used for the catalytic degradation of mycotoxins. The authors examine the efficacy of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts in degrading mycotoxins associated with various types of fungi, including Aspergillus and Fusarium species. The study evaluates the performance of these nanomaterials in terms of their catalytic activity, stability, and reusability. The authors also discuss the potential applications of these nanomaterials in food safety, environmental remediation, and human health. This paper highlights the importance of nanomaterials in the degradation of mycotoxins, which are known to have toxic effects on humans and animals. The study emphasizes the need for further research in this area to develop more effective and sustainable methods for mycotoxin degradation.  Through the Patchy Anthropocene lens, the duality of mycotoxins as both pathogens and resources becomes apparent. While mycotoxins pose a significant threat to human and animal health, they can also be used as industrial catalysts in the production of various chemicals. The development of nanomaterials that can degrade mycotoxins highlights the tension between the need to control and eliminate these toxins and the need to utilize them as resources. This study reveals the complex relationships between human and nonhuman actors in the production and degradation of mycotoxins, highlighting the importance of considering the material entanglements between microorganisms, nanomaterials, and human activities.

source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles

summary: This study investigated the effects of T-2 toxin on three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin.   T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by Fusarium species, was found to inhibit protein synthesis and induce oxidative stress in cells. In magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures, T-2 toxin treatments of 100, 500, and 1,000 nM for 48 and 72 hours resulted in decreased metabolic activity, measured using the CCK-8 assay. The levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG, markers of oxidative homeostasis, were significantly altered by T-2 toxin exposure.   The metabolic activity of the cells was alleviated after 72 hours, suggesting a possible adaptive response. T-2 toxin exposure led to decreased levels of MDA and HSP27 after 48 hours, indicating disrupted oxidative homeostasis. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced after 72 hours exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin, suggesting a possible adaptive response to oxidative stress. The levels of IL-6 and IL-8, markers of immune response, were also altered by T-2 toxin exposure, with 1,000 nM T-2 toxin decreasing IL-6 levels after 48 and 72 hours and all toxin treatments lowering IL-8 levels after 72 hours.  The adverse effects of T-2 toxin on hepatic cell cultures highlight its potential to disrupt cellular function and induce oxidative stress. Through the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function, T-2 toxin can compromise the health of poultry. This study's findings underscore the need for further research on the impact of T-2 toxin on avian health and the poultry industry.  The T-2 toxin's capacity to disrupt cellular function and induce oxidative stress in chicken hepatic cells underscores its potential as a pathogen, compromising avian health. title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. summary: The source data is limited to a case report, which describes the treatment of a 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis. The patient developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation. This case report highlights the tension between the use of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions as a treatment for mucormycosis and their potential to cause severe skin damage, which can be mitigated with proper nursing interventions. The management of this patient's skin injury underscores the complex entanglement of clinical efficacy, material toxicity, and bedside care in the treatment of immunocompromised patients.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. summary: This study evaluated the diagnostic criteria for invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injuries. The research involved a retrospective cohort study of 276 patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023, with at least 15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. The study examined direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction (quantitative polymerase chain reaction) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium, and serum galactomannan. Among 6,184 samples, 489 were positive, including 281 skin biopsies and 132 plasma specimens. Positive diagnostic criteria were found in 93 patients, with 25.7% positive for Aspergillus, 10.9% for Mucorales, and 9.8% for Fusarium. The study found a correlation between mortality and the number of positive criteria, with 46.7% mortality in patients with 5 or more positive criteria. The results suggest that combining skin biopsies with species-specific plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction enhances timely and reliable invasive fungal disease diagnosis in burn patients. The coexistence of multiple mold species was also found to correlate with increased mortality, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment.   This study's findings highlight the dual nature of invasive mold infections in burn patients, where these pathogens can both pose a significant threat to life and serve as a resource for diagnostic and therapeutic applications. title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This study investigated the protective effects of dietary curcumin (CUR) supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to aflatoxin B1 (AFB1). AFB1, a potent mycotoxin, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. The study used a controlled experimental design to evaluate the efficacy of CUR in mitigating AFB1-induced hepatotoxicity. The results showed that dietary CUR supplementation alleviated AFB1-induced liver injury and improved growth performance in broilers. This was attributed to CUR's activation of the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) pathway and inhibition of the NLRP3 inflammasome. The study suggests that CUR could be a potential dietary remedy for alleviating AFB1-induced liver injury and growth retardation in broilers.  Through the Patchy Anthropocene lens, the findings highlight the entanglement of human, nonhuman, and material relations in the production of poultry feed and the consequences of improper storage practices. The aflatoxin B1 mycotoxin, a byproduct of fungal growth on contaminated feed, reveals the hidden costs of industrial agriculture and the material dependencies that shape the health and growth of broilers. Meanwhile, the curcumin compound derived from the plant Curcuma longa underscores the potential for plant-based remedies to mitigate the effects of environmental toxins and industrial pathogens, highlighting the complex and often contradictory relationships between human and nonhuman actors in the Anthropocene.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: This study investigated the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (single nucleotide polymorphisms) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus. The researchers analyzed 34 cyp51A variants from clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022. They focused on novel, recent mutations, specifically the single nucleotide polymorphisms L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S, as well as the combinations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S.   The study used the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique to introduce the mutations into the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain, and then conducted in vitro susceptibility testing to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The results showed that the minimum inhibitory concentrations of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type. Specifically, the genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole.  This research highlights the complex relationship between molecular dynamics simulations and the structure-function relationship of in vitro phenotype in the context of azole resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus. The findings underscore the need for a nuanced understanding of the interplay between genetic mutations and azole susceptibility in this pathogen.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. summary: This study reports the identification and characterization of a novel antifungal compound, compound 1, isolated from the soil microbe Kitasatospora melanogena. The compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity against four fungal pathogens, including Aspergillus fumigatus, with minimum inhibitory concentrations (minimum inhibitory concentrations) ranging from 4 to 16 μg/mL. Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus, as well as a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, resulting in elevated levels of reactive oxygen species. The study's findings highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents, underscoring the importance of soil microbes as a valuable reservoir for antifungal compounds. The identification of a novel polyene macrolide with a multifaceted mechanism of action, disrupting both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, reveals a promising avenue for addressing the pressing need for new antifungal treatments.   The compound's ability to target multiple cellular components and induce oxidative stress underscores the complex and adaptive nature of fungal pathogens, which in turn highlights the need for novel, multifaceted antifungal agents that can effectively counteract the evolving threats posed by these organisms. The study's findings reflect the broader patterns of exposure and vulnerability shaped by human activities, including the cultivation of soil-dwelling microbes for the production of novel bioactive compounds.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.
summary: This paper investigated the effect of doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles on tomato resistance to fungal pathogens, specifically Fusarium. Three types of cuboidal CuS micronanoparticles were used: undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS). In a greenhouse study, these CuS micronanoparticles were applied to Fusarium-infected tomato plants. The iron-doped CuS micronanoparticles resulted in higher copper accumulation in leaves, which was attributed to their positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient uptake. The application of iron-doped CuS micronanoparticles led to a significant increase in shoot biomass and a reduction in wilt damage through the activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS micronanoparticles as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant.  the potential of CuS micronanoparticles as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, but emphasizes the need for further evaluation of their long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts.  The findings of this study illustrate the complex entanglement of plant immunity and material properties. The iron-doped CuS micronanoparticles, which accumulated more copper in leaves, also triggered a stronger defense response against Fusarium, underscoring the dual role of CuS as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. This highlights the potential for CuS micronanoparticles to be used as a novel tool for plant disease management, while also raising questions about the long-term environmental implications of their use.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Deletion of genes encoding known fungicide targets revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting MoA prediction. Using the platform that detects sensitivity differences through OD₆₀₀ changes, we examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. Collectively, this platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. summary: This study established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. The platform involved deleting genes encoding known fungicide targets by homologous recombination and examining the resulting mutants' sensitivity to corresponding fungicides. The deletion of genes revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting mode of action prediction. Using this platform, the researchers examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. The study's findings suggest that combining genetic approaches with chemical screening offers a more systematic way to identify candidate antifungal agents and better understand their mechanisms.  The capacity of this research to identify novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum highlights the material entanglement between chemical compounds, genetic pathways, and fungal pathogens. The discovery of previously unreported antifungal activity in 8 compounds underscores the potential for novel scaffolds in disease management, while also emphasizing the limitations of current fungicides due to resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: This study examined the effect of overexpressing the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 on lipid accumulation under static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation.  McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia when compared to the control strain under solid-state fermentation. Total fatty acid content also increased by 35.7% in mycelia, and in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight. Fatty acid profiling revealed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. Reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-quantitative polymerase chain reaction) showed that McLipin expression peaked at 24 hours under solid-state fermentation, coinciding with the upregulation of genes involved in lipid metabolism, including ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes.  The enhancement of lipid yield through McLipin overexpression in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 under solid-state fermentation highlights the potential of this fungus as a resource for industrial lipid production. This finding can be seen as a material entanglement, where the oleaginous fungus becomes a vehicle for accumulation and resource extraction, illustrating the Patchy Anthropocene's theme of 'located relations between humans and nonhumans' within the broader material transformations and ruptures brought on by human activities. The study's results demonstrate how the manipulation of microbial metabolism can be leveraged for industrial purposes, underscoring the complex interplay between biological and economic processes.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%). Out of 107 patients, eight died (8/107, 7.5%); six of these deaths occurred in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and two in patients with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: This study analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals to assess the production of gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (epipolythiodioxopiperazine) toxin, in various fungal species. The isolates were from Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, Aspergillus terreus, and other fungal species. The researchers used high-performance liquid chromatography (high-performance liquid chromatography) and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry) to detect gliotoxin production in the isolates. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings highlight the species-specific production of epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxins, with Aspergillus fumigatus being the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.  From the Patchy Anthropocene lens, this study reveals a material entanglement between fungal species, culture conditions, and toxin production. The detection of gliotoxin in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates but not in other species highlights the specificity of epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in different fungal species. This specificity may be shaped by the complex interplay between fungal metabolism, environmental factors, and host-pathogen interactions. The production of gliotoxin, a potent toxin, in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates may have significant implications for human health, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper describes the isolation and characterization of decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Eight new compounds (pyrrospirones R-Y, 1-8) and 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated and their structures were determined through extensive spectroscopic analysis. The absolute configurations of these compounds were established using quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (electronic circular dichroism) spectra, comparison of experimental electronic circular dichroism spectra, or single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 has a unique polycyclic system consisting of a 6/5/6/5/6/13 arrangement. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for compounds 1 and 2 was proposed. The isolated compounds exhibited cytotoxic activity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116, with IC50 values ranging from 7.3 to 79.3 μM. Additionally, compounds 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 demonstrated antibacterial activity against six pathogenic bacteria, with minimum inhibitory concentration values ranging from 1.6 to 13.0 μg/mL.  Through the lens of the Patchy Anthropocene, this research highlights the entangled relationships between marine-derived fungi, human health, and the environment. The discovery of these compounds with antibacterial and cytotoxic properties reveals the potential of marine fungi as a source of novel bioactive molecules. However, the same species that produce these compounds can also contribute to the degradation of marine ecosystems and the spread of invasive species. The complex interplay between human activities, such as overfishing and coastal development, and the natural world is reflected in the biosynthetic pathways and bioactivity of these compounds.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. summary: This study analyzed the performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network (convolutional neural network) in identifying mold species from clinical isolates. The researchers trained three variations of the Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural network on 4,000 images of mold cultures from 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp., Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. The model performed particularly well in identifying Cladosporium spp. with an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 99.9% ± 0.1%. The study found that early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging but improved significantly on days 3–5, and that the convolutional neural network outperformed human experts in many cases, especially in mature cultures.   The findings of this study highlight the tension between the need for rapid and accurate identification of mold species and the reliance on expert interpretation, which can be time-consuming and scarce in resource-limited settings. The use of low-cost smartphone imaging and convolutional neural networks integrated with expert time can offer a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, revealing the material entanglement between technology, expertise, and resource availability in the context of mold identification.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. GSNOR also participated in multiple biological processes in A. flavus; for that, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated virulence on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. This study further investigated the role of the key regulatory enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in the NO signaling pathway. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis. summary: This paper investigated the role of S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in Aspergillus flavus, a fungus responsible for aflatoxin production. The researchers identified a gene encoding GSNOR in A. flavus and demonstrated its activity during various life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. They found that GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide (NO) homeostasis, as its deletion resulted in elevated nitric oxide levels and sensitivity to exogenous nitric oxide stress. Additionally, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis, and attenuated virulence on kernels. Furthermore, the study found that GSNOR deletion significantly elevated mycelial reactive oxygen species (reactive oxygen species) levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. The findings indicate that GSNOR plays a crucial role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis in A. flavus.  The Patchy Anthropocene lens reveals a complex relationship between GSNOR and aflatoxin production. On one hand, GSNOR is essential for maintaining nitric oxide homeostasis and reactive oxygen species balance, which are critical for fungal development and pathogenicity. However, the deletion of GSNOR also resulted in reduced aflatoxin production, suggesting that GSNOR may also play a role in promoting aflatoxin biosynthesis. This paradox highlights the tension between the need to regulate NO and reactive oxygen species levels for fungal survival and the potential benefits of targeting these pathways for aflatoxin control.
